segments.Text: A comprehensive document covering the general theory of groups, including definitions, properties, and examples.
Group Theory
Definition
A group (G, *) consists of a set G and a binary operation * such that:

content.Text: ∃ e ∈ G : ∀ a ∈ G : e ∘ a = a ∘ e = a
∀ a ∈ G : ∃ a⁻¹ ∈ G : a ∘ a⁻¹ = a⁻¹ ∘ a = e

segments.Text: Properties
Groups can have various properties:
- Abelian/Commutative: If a * b = b * a for all a, b ∈ G
- Finite/Infinite: Whether the group has a finite or infinite number of elements
- Simple: If the group has no proper normal subgroups
- Solvable: If the group has a subnormal series with abelian factors
- Nilpotent: If the lower central series terminates at the identity
Examples
Common examples of groups include:
- Integers under addition: (Z, +)
- Non-zero rational numbers under multiplication: (Q\{0}, ×)
- Symmetric groups: S_n (permutations of n elements)
- Cyclic groups: Z_n or C_n (integers modulo n)
- Matrix groups: GL(n, F) (n×n invertible matrices over a field F)
Topological Group

content.Text: (Parametric { parameters: {}, description: "Abstract group set", membership_condition: "x ∈ G", properties: VariantSet { inner: {} } }, τ on Parametric { parameters: {}, description: "Abstract topological space", membership_condition: "x ∈ G", properties: VariantSet { inner: {} } })

segments.Text: A topological group is a mathematical structure that combines the algebraic structure of a group with the geometric structure of a topology in a compatible way.
Formally, a topological group G is a group (G, ·, e, ⁻¹) equipped with a topology such that the group operations are continuous functions.
Underlying algebraic structure:

Link.tooltip: View the underlying group structure with closure, associativity, identity, and inverses

segments.Text: — provides the algebraic framework with binary operation, identity element, and inverses.
Underlying geometric structure:

Link.tooltip: View the underlying topological space with open sets, continuity, and convergence

segments.Text: — provides the geometric framework with open sets, neighborhoods, and continuity.
Compatibility Requirements: The algebra and geometry must be compatible through continuity of group operations:
• Multiplication μ: G × G → G, (x,y) ↦ x·y must be continuous
• Inversion ι: G → G, x ↦ x⁻¹ must be continuous
This specific topological group is constructed on the set Parametric { parameters: {}, description: "Abstract group set", membership_condition: "x ∈ G", properties: VariantSet { inner: {} } }:
Level 1 (General Schema): This represents the abstract mathematical concept of topological groups, providing the foundational framework that all specific topological groups must satisfy.
Classical Examples: ℝ (real numbers under addition), S¹ (circle group), GL(n,ℝ) (general linear group), SL(n,ℝ) (special linear group), O(n) (orthogonal group), U(n) (unitary group).
Applications: Lie group theory, harmonic analysis, representation theory, gauge theory in physics, and symmetric spaces in differential geometry.
Mathematical Significance: Topological groups bridge algebra and geometry, providing the foundation for modern harmonic analysis, representation theory, and differential geometry.
Key Theorems: Haar's theorem (existence of invariant measure), Peter-Weyl theorem (decomposition of representations), and the structure theory of locally compact groups.
Physical Applications: Gauge theories, crystal structures, particle physics symmetries, and quantum mechanical systems all rely heavily on topological group theory.
(G, τ)

content.Text: Lie(Parametric { parameters: {}, description: "Abstract group set", membership_condition: "x ∈ G", properties: VariantSet { inner: {} } }, τ)

segments.Text: A Lie group is a group that is also a differentiable manifold, with the property that the group operations (multiplication and inversion) are smooth (infinitely differentiable) functions.

Definition: A Lie group is a set G equipped with both a group structure and a smooth manifold structure such that the group operations μ: G × G → G (multiplication) and ι: G → G (inversion) are smooth maps.
Key Properties: Every Lie group is locally Euclidean, and near the identity element, the group structure is determined by its Lie algebra.
Classical Examples: GL(n, ℝ) (general linear group), SL(n, ℝ) (special linear group), O(n) (orthogonal group), SO(n) (special orthogonal group), U(n) (unitary group), SU(n) (special unitary group).
Applications: Lie groups are fundamental in differential geometry, physics (symmetries of physical systems), representation theory, and the study of differential equations.
For the underlying group structure, see
Manifold Topology: Parametric { parameters: {}, description: "Abstract Lie group manifold", membership_condition: "x ∈ G", properties: VariantSet { inner: {} } }
This is L1: A general schema for any Lie group.
ℤ
A cyclic group is a group that is generated by a single element. Every element in the group can be expressed as a power of this generator.
Definition: A group G is cyclic if there exists an element g ∈ G such that G = ⟨g⟩ = {g^n | n ∈ ℤ}.
Infinite Cyclic Group: ℤ represents the infinite cyclic group of integers under addition.
Properties: ℤ is the unique (up to isomorphism) infinite cyclic group.
Generator: Symbol("g")
Applications: Cyclic groups appear in modular arithmetic, crystallography, Fourier analysis, and as building blocks for more complex algebraic structures.
For the underlying group structure, see
This is L1: A general schema for any cyclic group.

The alternating group consists of all even permutations on n elements.
This is L1: A general schema for any alternating group.
Modulus: 0
Additive group of integers modulo n under addition.
This is a cyclic group of order 0.
Modulus: 0
Multiplicative group of units modulo n under multiplication.
This group consists of integers coprime to the modulus.
Rank: 0
Free group on the given number of generators.
The most general group with the given generators, subject only to the group axioms.
The trivial group, containing only the identity element.
This is the unique group of order 1.

G/N
Parent Group: G
Normal Subgroup: N
Quotient group formed by the cosets of the normal subgroup.
ker(φ)
The kernel of a group homomorphism φ.
This is the set of elements that map to the identity in the codomain.
The kernel is always a normal subgroup of the domain.
im(φ)
The image of a group homomorphism φ.
This is the set of all elements in the codomain that have a preimage.
The image is always a subgroup of the codomain.
Z(G)
The center Z(G) of a group G.
This is the set of elements that commute with every element of G.
The center is always a normal subgroup.
Number of generators: 1
The subgroup generated by the given elements.
This is the smallest subgroup containing all the generators.
N_G(H)
The normalizer N_G(H) of a subgroup H in G.
This is the largest subgroup of G in which H is normal.
The normalizer always contains H as a normal subgroup.
C_G(x)
The centralizer C_G(x) of an element x in G.
This is the set of elements in G that commute with x.
The centralizer is always a subgroup of G.
[G,G]
The commutator subgroup [G,G] of a group G.
This is the subgroup generated by all commutators [g,h] = ghg⁻¹h⁻¹.
The commutator subgroup is always normal, and G/[G,G] is abelian.
Syl_0(G)
Prime: 0
A Sylow p-subgroup of the given group.
This is a maximal p-subgroup, where the order is a power of the prime.
G ≀ H
The wreath product G ≀ H of groups G and H.
This construction combines the direct product with a group action.
Elements are pairs (f, h) where f: H → G is a function and h ∈ H.
G ∘ H
G ×_H K
The pullback (fibered product) G ×_H K of groups over a common target H.
This is a universal construction in the category of groups.
Elements are pairs (g, k) where g ∈ G and k ∈ K such that φ(g) = ψ(k).
G|_S
The restriction G|_S of a group G to a subset S.
This construction restricts the group operation to a specific subset.
The subset S must satisfy specific conditions to form a valid subgroup.
